The reason I do this?

I've been jobless many times. And it shucks. 

I know my 300k network can be put to good use vs. me giving you yet another educational post on personal branding or whatever other marketing ploy.

Remember: This is not a B2B platform. Or B2C.

It's H2H = Human to Human. Forever. ❤️

Thanks a million.

sample_posts.hook: I got booked out 3 years in a row with LinkedIn
sample_posts.full_content:
I got booked out 3 years in a row with LinkedIn

(without sending a single cold DM)

Look, I'm not against cold DMing or outreach to prospects → I'm against doing it too soon. Truth is:

Most of you DM complete "strangers".

They don't know you. They can smell your sale coming from a mile away. So 99.9% of the time, it's crickets.

Instead, focus on "warm outreach":

1. Write super-valuable comments / replies
2. Don't merely "respond" → "add" to posts
3. Actively look for your ICPs on others' posts
4. On your own posts, prioritize ICP comments
5. On your own posts, respond to new folks too!
6. Create a sheet with your "warmest" prospects
7. Track how many interactions you have with them
8. After minimum 5 / optimally 10 → reach out via DM

(I built my own tool for warm outreach → Linkbound)

99% of the time, I get a response here. Why?

Because the familiarity is already there.
Because I've already built trust. They know me.
Because I've earned the right to "sell" at this point.

Any sooner than 5 interactions? Not sure.

Build familiarity → Build trust → Build ANY business

Hope this helps, friend! (Repost ♻️ if so)

P.S. Do you ever "actively" look for your Ideal Client Profiles in other people's comments? I do all the time.

sample_posts.hook: Confession: I quit LinkedIn 2 years in a row.
sample_posts.full_content:
Confession: I quit LinkedIn 2 years in a row.

(I was focused on the wrong things)

My first year, 5 days. My second, 5 weeks.

That's how long it took for me to bail out: "LinkedIn ain't working for me. I have no idea what I'm doing. Nobody is liking my posts. Nobody is reaching out."

Until I got back to the basics:

1. Be in front of new people → spend 90% of your daily activity in the comments (on other people's posts)

2. Engage the right people → DM those warm prospects and show them opportunities, not problems  

3. Use content to drive traffic to your profile → 1 and 2 above are manual, but inbound leads come to you

Building relationships.

That's all there is to it, really...

Meet people → Engage people → Help people. 

The greatest athletes have done the same exercise for 3,000 days straight. The most basic exercises, yep. Zero "hacks". In business, it's the same.

Repost if you value business basics ♻️

P.S. Ever thought of quitting here? Let's chat.

sample_posts.creator: justinwelsh
sample_posts.hook: Noise is the enemy of clarity.
sample_posts.full_content:
Noise is the enemy of clarity.

In a world that celebrates busy — 

Having a quiet mind is a superpower.

My best decisions come when I think in silence, not when I'm in the middle of total chaos.

When I put my phone in the other room and simply sit with my thoughts, things change.

My ideas start to connect.
Paths forward become more obvious.
Solutions appear that I couldn't see before.

But being quiet isn't natural nowadays.

It requires some practice.

For years, I fought against it  — thinking that constant action and noise meant constant growth.

I was wrong.

The most successful entrepreneurs I know understand this counterintuitive truth: 

Subtraction will often create more value than addition.

So, they've built systems to filter out noise.
To protect their mental space.
To design their days around deep work.

So, if you're struggling to move forward, don't add things to your plate.

Ask:

"What can I subtract today?"

That just might be your answer.

P.S. If you want to build a business through smart systems, check out The Creator MBA. Over 19 hours of video, I guide you through building your first online business from scratch: https://lnkd.in/gBnHYrjW

sample_posts.hook: There's a weird behavior I've noticed on LinkedIn:
sample_posts.full_content:
There's a weird behavior I've noticed on LinkedIn: 

Constant criticism and anger.

People trying to build their following by tearing others down.

Writing content about why Person X is a fraud, Company Y is doing it wrong, or Expert Z doesn't know what they're talking about. 

It's the business equivalent of trying to become the tallest person in the room by pushing everyone else to their knees.

But here's the thing — that stuff is easy.

Anyone can point out flaws. 
Anyone can play the role of the cynic. 

What's hard, what *actually* requires skill and creates value, is building something worth paying attention to. 

Something that stands on its own merit, not on the ruins of someone else's work.

The most influential voices I know aren't the ones who spent their time dissecting why everyone else is wrong.

Instead:

They show us a better way.
They create art that moves us.
They share advice that helps us think.
They build products that change our lives.

Their influence came from contribution, not criticism.

Of course, there's a place for critique and analysis. 

But if that's your only pitch for attention – "listen to me because those other people are wrong" – you're building on a foundation of sand. 

You're growing an audience that values negativity over creation. 

And eventually...inevitably...

That same audience will turn that critical lens back on you.

Want real influence? 

Build something worth talking about. 

The rest will follow.

If you want insights learned from building a $9M+ business without engaging in negativity, I share them weekly: https://lnkd.in/eZReQh7W

Cheers (and stay positive).

sample_posts.full_content:
- A common disease in some Silicon Valley circles: a misplaced superiority complex.
- Symptom of advanced stage: thinking your small tribe has a monopoly on good ideas.
- Symptom of terminal stage: assuming innovations from elsewhere are obtained through cheating.

Science and technology progress faster when larger numbers of talented people are involved and *share* their innovations.

In fact, that's why:
- the scientific community is organized around publications and tool sharing
- the developers community is organized around open source
- the patent system exists (despite being outdated and counterproductive for software and services): you may get a short, government-mandated exclusivity on the use of your invention, but in exchamge, you must disclose enough information for others to reproduce it and build on top of it.

name: andrewyng

sample_posts.creator: andrewyng
sample_posts.hook: AI Product Management
sample_posts.full_content:
AI Product Management

AI Product Management is evolving rapidly. The growth of generative AI and AI-based developer tools has created numerous opportunities to build AI applications. This is making it possible to build new kinds of things, which in turn is driving shifts in best practices in product management — the discipline of defining what to build to serve users — because what is possible to build has shifted. In this post, I’ll share some best practices I have noticed.

Use concrete examples to specify AI products. Starting with a concrete idea helps teams gain speed. If a product manager (PM) proposes to build “a chatbot to answer banking inquiries that relate to user accounts,” this is a vague specification that leaves much to the imagination. For instance, should the chatbot answer questions only about account balances or also about interest rates, processes for initiating a wire transfer, and so on? But if the PM writes out a number (say, between 10 and 50) of concrete examples of conversations they’d like a chatbot to execute, the scope of their proposal becomes much clearer. Just as a machine learning algorithm needs training examples to learn from, an AI product development team needs concrete examples of what we want an AI system to do. In other words, the data is your PRD (product requirements document)!

In a similar vein, if someone requests “a vision system to detect pedestrians outside our store,” it’s hard for a developer to understand the boundary conditions. Is the system expected to work at night? What is the range of permissible camera angles? Is it expected to detect pedestrians who appear in the image even though they’re 100m away? But if the PM collects a handful of pictures and annotates them with the desired output, the meaning of “detect pedestrians” becomes concrete. An engineer can assess if the specification is technically feasible and if so, build toward it. Initially, the data might be obtained via a one-off, scrappy process, such as the PM walking around taking pictures and annotating them. Eventually, the data mix will shift to real-word data collected by a system running in production.

Using examples (such as inputs and desired outputs) to specify a product has been helpful for many years, but the explosion of possible AI applications is creating a need for more product managers to learn this practice.

Assess technical feasibility of LLM-based applications by prompting. When a PM scopes out a potential AI application, whether the application can actually be built — that is, its technical feasibility — is a key criterion in deciding what to do next. For many ideas for LLM-based applications, it’s increasingly possible for a PM, who might not be a software engineer, to try prompting — or write just small amounts of code — to get an initial sense of feasibility.

[Reached length limit. Full text: https://lnkd.in/gYY-hvHh ]

You’ll build a world with hierarchical content generation, a method that allows you to leverage LLMs to create a vast amount of content with a high level of control and consistency. With hierarchical content generation, you can create information about your world, shape its direction with a human-in-the-loop, and keep it consistent, with little effort based on your prompts.

By the end of this course, you’ll know how to prompt engineer to create a layered and interwoven world and integrate it into an AI roleplay game that is interesting, interactive, and safe to share with anyone.

sample_posts.full_content:
It’s RB2B’s 1st birthday! We’re just shy of $5m ARR and very profitable. Yet, I sit here anxious and annoyed about an outcome I should be grateful for. Why?

I think we could have done so much better. 

Why?

1. We identified the “filtering, routing, and what now” problems 5mo in, but 
2. Didn’t start making real moves to solve them until around a month ago.

As a result, our churn rate has been a source of great frustration and disappointment.

Here are the four biggest mistakes I think we made over the past four months:  

- We JUST built the Salesforce integration for our larger prospects
- We JUST rebuilt our Hubspot integration to filter, route, alert, add to lead score, and start automations within the CRM
- We STILL have not teed up suggested messages using AI (the “what now”?)
- I ROYALLY screwed up our pricing on launch, and cost us 2mo of growth

If I had to do it all over again I would have done things sooo differently.

But that's almost the case in startup-land.

———

Having said all that... 

I’m very optimistic that we can hit $10m ARR in the next 12mo.

Even though $10m will be MUCH harder than $5m because of our high churn.

What are our plans for the next 12mo? 

1. Add worldwide, company-level ID, partnered with DemandBase
2. Add a job change signal (and then others)
3. Resolve the “what now” problem using AI

Strategically, we want to try to get reps valuable signals with the simplest possible delivery, WITHOUT having to adopt a new platform, at a great price.

We think we can do most of what needs to be done in the CRM… 

For a HIGH percentage of the workflows our competitors accomplish in their platforms.

And we think that NOT adopting a platform is very attractive to a large part of the market.

I have no idea if this is the right move… 

And it’s certainly going the opposite direction of anyone doing anything like us.

But that’s the thing that makes me the most excited about it. 

Stupid Simple Sales Signals. 

It has a nice ring to it.

sample_posts.full_content:
On my run this morning, I was listening to "How to Make a Few Billion Dollars" by Brad Jacobs (founder of 7x billion-dollar businesses). He had an incredible take on hiring A Players vs B Players vs C Players:

The old adage is that A Players hire B Players.

And B Players hire C Players.

So never let B Players hire.

But Brad's take on it was simpler...

No C Players at all.

Have a short leash with B Players.

And give your A Players everything. 

---

The real question is:

How do you recognize A vs B vs C Players? 

The way he defined it is perfect...

When an A Player walks into your office to quit, you're reaction is: 

No. This business doesn't run without you. What do you need? What can I give you? It's literally debilitating for them to quit. 

When a B Player walks into your office to quit, your reaction is:

Ouch, this hurts. Definitely inconvenient. But I can probably find somebody to fill the role, maybe somebody who's even a little better than you.

When a C Player walks into your office to quit, your reaction is:

We were probably gonna let you go anyway.

---

The goal according to him is simple:

Don't have C Players at all. 

If you think that way about anybody... 

The time to have that conversation is now.

Anybody out there operating this way?

It's very, very hard.

sample_posts.creator: codiesanchez
sample_posts.hook: If you want to acquire a million-dollar company, you don’t need to have millions.
sample_posts.full_content:
If you want to acquire a million-dollar company, you don’t need to have millions.

Here’s how to buy a business that pays for itself (9 negotiation tips for seller financing):

First up, seller financing means you agree to pay the seller back over time directly using the profits of the business.

Why would you want to do such a thing?

2 main reasons:

• You pay less out of pocket, without needing bank approval.
• The seller keeps skin in the game. It's now in their best interest to give you a business that will continue to profit.

Sounds great as a buyer, but why would a seller ever say yes to this?

• It’s faster than bank loans
• They can ask for a higher price
• They pocket interest, instead of the bank
• Tax payments get dispersed

But there are some hurdles to seller financing:

• It’s harder than applying for a bank loan
• Sellers need to be “sold” on it
• Many sellers will still say no

So let’s look at 9 ways to increase your odds of seller financing a deal:

1. ALWAYS ASK.

Seller financing isn’t all or nothing. ALWAYS feel out how much the seller will finance. Maybe you only get $300k on a $3M deal. That's $300k not out of YOUR pocket.

2. Relationship Is the Foundation

Your odds of getting financing increase as your rapport with the seller increases.

3. Seller Risk

You’ll get pushback. Get to the bottom of WHY the seller is hesitant. It’s often not a no, just an “I’m not so sure.” Find out what will make them sure.

4. Your Price, My Terms

Seller wants $250k more for the biz? Alright, then you the buyer get to hold the reigns on the interest rate, length of payback period, and other levers.

5. Presentation

You are PITCHING a seller, so go back to negotiation 101:
• Don’t play all your cards at once
• Focus on where the seller’s head is at & what they need to move the deal forward

6. Throwaway Terms

The seller’s mind is running through worst case scenarios. Most of those scenarios have a .0001% chance of happening, so you can put them in the contract anyway.

7. Fallback Positions

These are backup terms you don’t want to lead with, but would compromise for.

8. Knowledge vs Wisdom

Keep rebuttals to seller concerns in your back pocket. But don’t just rattle off a bunch of terms and benefits. Understand their fear/concern → then propose the solution for it

9. Creative Solutions

Every deal is full of problems. The fun of it is finding creative solutions.

Don't let "this is the usual way" stop you from "this makes me more."

Related:

TOMORROW you can get live teaching from experts + breakout sessions with like-minded people on:

• Seller financing
• Deal clarity
• Financial analysis
• & the rest of the acquisition process

I don't know why a bunch of band of vibe coders don't band together to vibe code free AI-powered alternatives to SaaS incumbents like Figma ($20B), Adobe ($16B ARR), DocuSign ($2.5B ARR) etc. 

This gotta be the most obvious  $100M+/year startup idea of our time.

So, legacy SaaS companies are sitting ducks. Their products were designed in a pre-AI world, with pre-AI economics. They have massive teams, expensive infrastructure, and shareholders demanding consistent growth.

And more people than ever want to use these products, but they don't want to pay another monthly subscription. 

Meanwhile, a small team of vibe coders could band together tomorrow and build 90%+ of the functionality in weeks, not years and offer it for FREE to 99% of users. Thanks to tools like Replit, V0, Cursor, Bolt, Lovable etc and all these open-source models.

And instead of charging monthly, you give it out for free, and charge power users per outcome. And you can layer on premium service to cash flow (I can talk about that on another tweet on what I'd do)

What's holding people back? Is it the fear of taking on giants? The allure of building something "new" instead of "better"? Or people just like building on their own so they don't want to band together?

I think the avg customer prefers a one-stop shop for all these free new AI saas powered tools. 

You don't need to raise VC if you don't want to. 

Every time I open one of these legacy products and see the same old interfaces with the same old limitations, I can't help but think we're at the beginning of a massive wealth transfer from incumbents to the teams bold enough to rebuild them from scratch.

I'm not saying these incumbents are going to die btw. But I do think there's an opportunity (yeah a really big one) to peel off some of their sweet saas revenue and monetize it differently. Make it free for most. 

Nothing people hate more than a monthly subscription. 

Happy building.

sample_posts.hook: Are we going to pretend $750/hour law firms are going to be business as usual in the AI age?
sample_posts.full_content:
Are we going to pretend $750/hour law firms are going to be business as usual in the AI age?

I just used Grok Deep Research to draft a simple contract. Took 15 minutes. Would have cost $2,000 with a lawyer. 

When I sent it to my attorney to review, his response was "looks good" 2 days later.

I had already sent the contract lol. It was signed by the client. Thanks Mr. Attorney.

Lawyers and accountants keep insisting that AI is just a toy and real work requires human judgment. Meanwhile, their billable hours model is silently imploding.

I've watched this pattern play out before. First comes denial. Then "it only works for simple stuff." Then "it can't handle nuance." Finally, massive restructuring.

Law firms won't disappear, but the pyramid of junior associates doing document review and contract drafting is evaporating overnight. What nobody's talking about is how the next generation will learn when the entry-level jobs that have always been the training ground are precisely what AI does best.

I wouldn't be surprised if the biggest shock to law firms comes when their own clients start bringing AI-drafted documents to meetings and just asking for quick reviews. 

The real change won't be dramatic - it'll be the slow realization that clients are paying for 1 hour of work instead of 10, while still getting the same outcome. 

It'll be death by a thousand cuts as more routine legal work gets handled by in-house teams with AI assistance.

We're watching the complete reinvention of professional services happen in real-time, and pretending nothing will change.

sample_posts.hook: 5 “basic” LinkedIn tips that are actually incredibly effective:
sample_posts.full_content:
5 “basic” LinkedIn tips that are actually incredibly effective:

1. Write effective hooks

Your hook—the first 10% of your post—decides whether or not people read the last 90% of it.

Like it or not, you’re competing for attention.

If your hook isn’t interesting, your readers will scroll to something more interesting.

2. Be consistent

Publishing content on LinkedIn consistently is the price of entry—you can’t succeed without it.

That said, consistency isn’t enough by itself.

Your target needs to be undeniably valuable to a clearly defined target audience who can pay for more of your knowledge.

Interview your target market to learn their pain points. Then, build content pillars around each of those pain points.

Results are inevitable.

3. Respond to your comments

LinkedIn values community much more than any other social media platform—

This means they want to see authors engaging with their audience (and other industry peers).

Creators who take the time to respond won’t just enjoy greater reach, but deeper audience connections, too.

4. Experiment with different formats

For most authors, written posts aren’t enough to make the most of LinkedIn anymore…

Carousels tend to get the most reach, while video creates the deepest psychological connections.

(There’s also some evidence LinkedIn is pushing videos more in the feed than it used to)

5. Write for your target audience

Stop trying to “go viral” and “go value” instead.

10,000,000 views from total strangers are worthless if they’re not interested in your actual expertise as a professional…

Sure, a few of them may hit the follow button, but they won’t stick around if you’re just another “influencer” handing out dopamine hits.

The real winners on LinkedIn focus on audience quality.

All it takes is the right impression on the right people to create high-paying clients (and life-changing results).

Those are some of my favorite “basic” LinkedIn tips—

What are yours?

sample_posts.hook: Most LinkedIn growth advice is dangerously bad.
sample_posts.full_content:
Most LinkedIn growth advice is dangerously bad.

Why?

It’s based on flawed thinking patterns that lead people to draw completely wrong conclusions.

People fall into 3 major traps when analyzing “what works” on LinkedIn:

1. The Success-Only Trap

They look only at what worked, never what failed.

It’s like studying only lottery winners to understand how to win the lottery.

2. The False Attribution Trap

They attribute success to things they can control instead of what matters:

Saying something worth paying attention to.

3. The Correlation Confusion

They mistake correlation for causation.

Just because something happened before success doesn’t mean it caused success.

And the truth is, the content format doesn’t matter (much).

What drives actual LinkedIn success is…

1. Credibility (Do people trust your expertise?)
2. Value (Are you saying something worth hearing?)
3. Clarity (Can people understand your point quickly?)
4. Luck (Will the algorithm pick it up? Will it show it to the right audience?)

Everything else is just optimization.

I’ve seen too many people chase vanity metrics that lead to zero business results.

Below, I break down the metrics that matter and how to build real LinkedIn success.

Read my complete guide for the full breakdown on how to cut through the “LinkedIn noise”:

https://lnkd.in/dJb_ZwSG

STOP Winging It When You Speak in Meetings

I see too many introverted leaders walking into meetings unprepared. 

Hoping their ideas will magically resonate with the room and then leaving feeling ignored or overlooked.

Do this instead:

1️⃣ Plan your key points in advance.
2️⃣ Practice speaking up within the first 5 minutes of the meeting.
3️⃣ Use strategic pauses to emphasize your ideas.
4️⃣ Maintain confident posture and eye contact to project authority.
5️⃣ End with a clear, actionable ask or statement.

The main reason why this failure happens is simple: most people underestimate the power of preparation and technique in commanding attention. 

They assume being introverted means staying quiet—and it’s costing them opportunities and respect.

Save yourself the frustration. 

Master these strategies and start communicating with confidence and clarity. 

You’ll stop being overlooked and start becoming the most wanted-to-be-heard voice in the room.

Repost ♻️ if you found this helpful.

sample_posts.creator: nealogrady
sample_posts.hook: It looks awful, but it works.
sample_posts.full_content:
It looks awful, but it works.

Why? We’ve all grown tired of perfect.

The Internet used to be hideous.

To compete, people stood out and built trust with better design and higher production value. YouTubers went from recording blurry vlogs to spending upwards of 6 to 7 figures per video.

In just two years, carousels on LinkedIn have gone from lazily cut and cropped Twitter threads.

To these incredibly well-designed, professional, and on-brand works of art took the creators 10+ hours and an experienced designer to make.

When everything is now manicured and over-optimized, how do you stand out?

👉 By embracing the ugly.

Ugly Ads work for a few reasons:

1️⃣ It's completely different than everything else in our feeds.

2️⃣ It's incomprehensible someone would make an ad that simple or ugly, so it's surprising and delightful.

Like when Surreal creates a billboard of a screenshot of a horrible ad made in PowerPoint.

3️⃣ They look and feel like organic posts.

4️⃣ We crave authenticity, simplicity, and rawness.

Fitness YouTuber Sam Sulek has grown to over 3M YouTube subscribers with hideous thumbnails, terrible titles, and horrible lighting.

It’s just him working out in a horribly lit gym and talking to the camera while driving home at night in his car.

In short:

Resist the urge for perfection.

Make some ads and posts that are a bit ugly and weird.

–––

PS: The best (and last) cohort of our audience building course, UNIGNORABLE, starts on Jan 20th. Check the link on my profile to join the waitlist for the Cyber Monday promos ;0

sample_posts.creator: nealogrady
sample_posts.hook: You don’t need “link building” trickery to rank in Google.
sample_posts.full_content:
You don’t need “link building” trickery to rank in Google.

Instead, you can go from 0 to 100k+ monthly views just by posting perfectly optimized blog posts 3x per week.

But what is a “perfectly optimized” post?

It's a blend of art and science.

Let’s dive in.

––––

✔️ SEO Metadata

Treat it like an ad or social post—it must be compelling to get people to click.

• Title: Write a compelling hook with your target keywords.
• Description: Treat it like ad copy, hook their interest so they click.
• URL: Match your target keywords.


✔️Schema markup

• Implement schema types like Article, BlogPosting, and Breadcrumbs so your content displays on the SERP.

If yours doesn’t, someone else’s will.


✔️ Original images

• Add alt tags to every image for SEO visibility and accessibility. Describe the key elements as if someone can’t see them.
• Break up large chunks of text with visuals.
• Stock photos, no thank you.


✔️ Content length:

• Aim for a minimum of 700 words, adjusting based on:

1. Competition:
If competitors are at 1,000 words, make a more thorough article that’s 1,500+ words.

2. Query specificity:
• Super specific keyword = short article.
• Broad keyword = extensive article.


✔️ Table of contents with anchor links:

• For longer articles (1,000+ words) add a table of contents to make it easy to jump to what they care about.


✔️ Heading structure:

• Use only one H1—the title of the article, ideally with the target keyword.
• Add supporting text under each heading to add context.
• Use H2s, H3s, and H4s appropriately.
• Make headings compelling. You have to keep them interested.


✔️ Internal links:

Internal links are essential. SEO experts say they’re more important than backlinks.

• Ensure every page has internal links leading to and from it.
• If you have a long article targeting a high-level keyword ( ), each section could link to another dedicated blog article
• Aim for posts to have 7+ internal links by cross-linking related articles.


✔️ HTML elements:

• Use lists, tables, and accordions to capture featured snippets.

It makes the article more delightful for readers so they stay longer.


✔️ YouTube embed:

• Pair each post with a YouTube video. Embedding videos act as backlinks and enhance visibility on Google and YouTube.

Shopify grew its YouTube to 230k subscribers in 18 months with this strategy.


✔️ Clear, compelling CTA

• Include clear CTAs throughout the article to turn readers into leads.
• Add contextually relevant lead magnets (email courses/PDFs) to each article.

Thanks to Rob Hoffman and Jake Ward for their help with this one!

sample_posts.full_content:
Subject lines are the hardest type of "hook" to write. So I created an AI prompt that makes it 10x easier:

But first, why is writing great subject lines so hard?

Simple:

Because you have a such big “length” constraint.

(For context: Ideally, a subject line can only have 40-45 characters.)

And the more concise you have to be, the harder it is to write something good - and the more thought it requires.

However, there’s 2 “hacks” that can make it 10x easier to write a potent subject line:

• Starting with an already proven hook (so you don’t need to start “from scratch)

• Using an AI tool like Claude or ChatGPT to accelerate your “brainstorming” process (so you can find the best formats & angles, faster)

So with this in mind, I created a plug-and-play AI prompt to help you write irresistible subject lines - 10x faster!

All you need?

A proven Twitter/X or LinkedIn hook.

It can be yours or it can be someone else’s.

Once you’ve found it, all you need to do is fill in the prompt below & feed it to your favorite AI tool.

Enjoy.

Here's the prompt:

"You’re a world-class email copywriter. I want your help turning a viral LinkedIn hook I recently found into an attention-grabbing subject line.

So, here's what we're going to do:

I'm going to share with you the LinkedIn hook and then I want you to come up with 15 different subject line variations inspired by that hook.

Now, here are a few important guidelines you should follow when brainstorming each subject line variation:

• The subject line shouldn't have more than 45 characters (including spaces)

• The subject line needs to be clear (not clever) but also create a "curiosity gap" (i.e. We can't give the reader the "answer." Instead we need to give them a reason to want to open the email.)

• The subject line should be formatted in sentence case (never capitalize the first letter of each word because we don't want our subject lines to read like an article headline).

• For each subject line variation we come up with, we also need to generate a "preview text." (For context: the "preview text" is the copy that shows up right next to or underneath the email subject line on people's inbox, and it acts almost a sub-headline.)

• The preview text should *complement* NOT repeat the same idea that's being communicated in the subject line. We also want to avoid repeating any words that have already been used in the headline. (Again, we want to use the "preview text" as a sub-headline.)

• Lastly, please structure your output in the following way:

[Heading] Subject Line X

• Subject line: [insert subject line variation]
• Preview text: [insert preview text variation]

So here you go - here's my LinkedIn hook:"

PS - Want to get this prompt in a Notion doc?

Comment "prompt" and I'll send it over (along with another bonus prompt).

sample_posts.creator: dbusta
sample_posts.hook: You only need 5 simple email flows to run a 7 figure digital product empire:
sample_posts.full_content:
You only need 5 simple email flows to run a 7 figure digital product empire:

🔸 Lead magnet nurture flow
🔸 Post-lead magnet sales flow
🔸 Abandoned cart follow-up flow
🔸 Evergreen nurture newsletter flow
🔸 New paid customer onboarding flow

Let’s break them down:

1️⃣ Lead magnet nurture flow

The goal of this flow is to keep nurturing your subscribers after they’ve downloaded your lead magnet.

That way, you can increase the odds they actually:

• Consume it
• Get value from it
• Keep opening your emails
• And eventually become paying customers

Usually, I recommend including 3-5 emails as part of this flow.

Some themes that tend to work well:

• Your personal backstory
• Common mistakes in your niche
• Additional resources they can find helpful
• Success stories from other clients/students

2️⃣ Post-lead magnet sales flow

The goal of this flow is to try to convert your most engaged subscribers into paying customers.

(Once you’ve nurtured them & provided a ton of value for a few days in a row.)

For this flow, I usually recommend sending 3-5 emails too.

But the big variable here is the price point of your paid offer.

The more expensive your product, the more emails you might need to send.

3️⃣ Abandoned cart follow-up flow

The goal of this flow is to maximize the number of people who buy from your post-lead magnet sales sequence.

How?

By sending a series of follow up emails (typically 1-3 emails) to your warmest leads.

Now, how do you know who those people are?

By tracking clicks!

Usually, I only send these follow-up emails to anyone who:

• Has clicked at least twice on any of my sales email links

• And hasn’t bought the product yet

(And yes, you can automate things so all of this happens on autopilot!)

4️⃣ Evergreen nurture newsletter flow

No matter how solid your lead magnet or sales emails are…

Most people won’t but after those initial 10-15 emails.

That’s why you need this flow.

The goal here is to keep nurturing & building trust with people who don’t buy right away until they:

• Either buy your paid product 
• Or unsubscribe from your list

Which basically means, this sequence will have infinite emails—and it will run forever.

The only caveat:

Every 60-90 days, you can:

• Momentarily remove folks from this flow
• Run a 5-7 day one-off campaign

This is a great way to convert people on the fence who might need a last push.

5️⃣ New paid customer onboarding flow

The goal of this flow is to:

• Onboard your new paid customers
• Check in with them so they stay engaged
• And keep nurturing them so they’re more likely to be successful 

Now, why does this matter?

Because if your customers are successful, they will:

• Give you a testimonial
• Buy all your future products
• And tell everyone about your product

And that’s it!

Enjoyed this? Gimme a follow - I share juicy email marketing frameworks like this every day.

And if you have any questions about any of these flows, lmk below - happy to help 👊

sample_posts.creator: johnrushx
sample_posts.hook: Why Startup Founders Fail:
sample_posts.full_content:
Why Startup Founders Fail: 

(based on my own failures & 100+ founders in my network)

1. Solution looking for a problem.
Founders build a solution first and then go to users, pitching it and trying to convince them they have such a problem.

2. They like it, but won't pay.
Often happens to "vitamin" products.

3. Failed to monetize b2c.
Once, I built an app with over 100k users, and was 1st on App Store with an award. But once I wanted to monetize it, I realized it was impossible to make good money here. 

4. Raised VC money for a non-unicorn idea.
VCs make 100 bets. You're just one of 100. The chance you fail is 99%, because for VCs anything is a failure except unicorns.
You could turn it into $10m/year biz in a bootstrapped mode, but VCs will force u to bankrupt such company.


5. Wrong cofounder.
When 2 people start a company, and 1 quits, the other one isn't that crazy about working their ass off for this startup to succeed.
Most startups I know that lost one of their cofounders early failed. I think cofounders bring more risk than upside.

6. Small market.
In Norway, where I spent most of my life building my startups, most would first start with a local market.
I thought it was smart, but the aftermath of the last 15 years shows that it was the reason for the downfall of the Norwegian startup ecosystem.

7. Outsourcing.
Think of it as hiring someone to raise your child.
This is a terrible idea in most cases.
Same for a startup. The single best predictor for a startup's failure is the fact that they outsource their tech.
Even worse: they outsource their marketing (before PMF)

8. Building a vitamin, not a painkiller.
Many founders don't have ideas. So they squeeze the idea out of the air, which often is a vitamin. It makes sense, but people can perfectly live without it.
A painkiller: u pitch someone & they nag you every week asking for access.

9. No passion for an audience & field.

10. Lack of focus.
Coding is easy now. I see too many founders jumping from idea to idea every month.
Nothing wrong with it, but for most, it'd make more sense to pivot existing ideas, instead of jumping into new ones.
It's best to become an expert in one field.

11. Not using their own product.

12. Not validating.

13. Bet on non organic growth.

14. Didn't plan for a marathon.

15. Out of money.

16. Not willing to learn, fixed on delegating.
Founders thinking: I'm the General, I'll find people better than me in each position, delegate & we will win cuz that's what Steve Jobs said.
In reality, founders must do all important work until PMF. Employees can't handle it.

17. That's it.
Besides the failures, I’ve built stuff millions use:

↳ https://listingbott.com ai agent that lists you on all relevant web directories.
↳ https://seobotai.com ai agent to run your blog 100% on autopilot.

"Elon has been wildly over-claiming and under-delivering on 'full self-driving' for almost a decade."

And the numbers tell the story for him:

• Tesla's "Full Self-Driving" is linked to 52 fatal accidents
• Their massive driving data provides only "marginal improvements"

Meanwhile, Waymo is dominating the actual robotaxi market:

• Operating in Phoenix, SF, LA, and Austin

And the contrast is undeniable:
While Tesla owners upload videos of cars running red lights and making dangerous highway maneuvers, Waymo is quietly scaling across America.

The overall consensus is that true autonomy is still a decade away - and it won't come from Tesla.

But Musk won't go down easily.

His response to critics:
"If somebody doesn't believe Tesla is going to solve autonomy, they should not be an investor in the company."

The moment of truth arrives this June in Austin.

Tesla's launching its first real robotaxi service - in the same city where Waymo just began operations last week.

The timing couldn't be more critical for Tesla's future.

This isn't just about Tesla versus Waymo.
It's about the future of AI safety and ethics in transportation.

When we put autonomous vehicles on public roads, we're not just testing technology – we're testing our commitment to human life.

The companies that prioritize safety over speed, transparency over hype, and scientific rigor over market caps will be the ones who write the next chapter of transportation.

They'll be the ones history remembers as pioneers who did it right.

sample_posts.hook: In 1967, Wall Street told her "No women allowed!"
sample_posts.full_content:
In 1967, Wall Street told her "No women allowed!" 
So when the NYSE charged her $4.2M for a seat...
She did what no woman had ever dared. 
Here's how Muriel Siebert became the Queen of Wall Street:

Muriel Siebert arrived in NYC with $500 and one goal: conquering Wall Street.

But firms wouldn't even look at her resume when they saw her first name.

Her solution? She began signing applications as "M. Siebert."

The interviews started flowing in immediately.

Her expertise in aerospace stocks quickly made her indispensable.

Then she discovered male colleagues earned 2x her salary for identical work.

The only path to equal pay? 
Buy a seat on the NYSE: $445,000 ($4.2M today).

But Wall Street revealed its true nature:
• 9 of 10 firms refused to sponsor her application
• Banks rejected her without a male signature
• NYSE demanded a $300,000 guarantee (never required for men)

After 2 years of persistence, Chase Manhattan finally approved her loan.

December 28, 1967: Siebert bought her seat, becoming the only woman among 1,365 men.

Then came the real obstacles:
• No women's restroom on the trading floor
• Barred from men-only clubs where deals happened
• Constant pressure to leave

Her response was legendary:
• Threatened to install a portable toilet on the floor
• Built her own powerful network
• Launched one of the first discount brokerages
• Became NY's first female Banking Superintendent

Under her leadership:
• Not a single bank failed
• She oversaw $500B in assets
• First NYSE room named after an individual
• Pioneered financial literacy in schools

Her words still resonate:
"For 10 years, I was the only woman out of 1,365 men. I didn't speak for two years. How do you talk to people who don't want you there?"

The lesson?

Siebert saw value where others saw barriers

Just like the best opportunities aren't where everyone's looking... 

They're where everyone says "impossible."

-

sample_posts.full_content:
In 2015, Google accidentally put their website up for sale. 
When a former employee realized it, he bought it for just $12.
Google had no choice but to give him whatever he wanted.
His response? Not $100,000. Not $100 Million.
Here's what he asked for instead:

When Sanmay Ved was browsing domains at 1:20 AM, he noticed something impossible.

Google .com was available for purchase. 

For $12.

So Ved did what any rational person would do and clicked "add to cart."

His heart stopped when the purchase went through.

In that moment, he owned the most valuable domain on earth.

He gained access to Google's internal webmaster tools and data.

He could've redirected billions in traffic.
He could've demanded millions in ransom.
He could've caused chaos.

Instead, he immediately reported it to Google's security team.

Google offered him a reward: $6,006.13 (spelling "Google" in leetspeak).

Ved's response? He asked them to donate it to an educational charity in India.

Google doubled the reward on the spot.

Not because Ved demanded it.

But because integrity inspired generosity.

The donation helped fund schools for underprivileged children.

One minute of domain ownership turned into years of education.

Sometimes the biggest opportunities aren't about what you can take.

They're about what you can give.

And in tech, where we chase the next big thing...

It's worth remembering that our greatest impact often comes from our smallest choices.

-

sample_posts.full_content:
In 1988, Oracle was threatening Microsoft's $12 BILLION empire.
So Bill Gates tried stealing their # 1 database to bankrupt them.
Oracle's response? A revenge plan Gates never saw coming (including spies)...
Here's the untold story of tech's craziest rivalry:

Microsoft ruled PCs, but Gates knew databases were the future of enterprise computing.

His solution? 

Drop $100M to create an "Oracle killer" by acquiring Sybase SQL Server's code.

But Larry Ellison wasn't about to watch his empire crumble.

Oracle's response was absolutely ruthless:
• Slashed prices to compete
• Rapidly innovated new features
• Hired private investigators to dig through Microsoft's trash
• Poached top talent aggressively

The rivalry got personal. Fast.

Both CEOs were obsessed with destroying each other.

Ellison's master plan?

The Network Computer - a $500 diskless computer designed to make Windows obsolete.

Gates countered by acquiring WebTV.

Then came Ellison's knockout punch:

Oracle provided evidence to the DOJ about Microsoft's monopolistic practices, leading to one of tech's biggest antitrust cases.

Game. Set. Match.

But here's where it gets interesting...

Fast forward to 2019: These bitter rivals announced a shocking cloud partnership.

Why? Because they realized something profound:

The enemy of my enemy is my friend.

The landscape had shifted. Cloud computing changed everything.

Now their partnership enables sub-millisecond latency between services.

The lesson?

Even the fiercest rivalries can transform into partnerships when the future demands it.

Because the next wave of innovation isn't about competition...

It's about connection.

Just like Gates and Ellison discovered: 
Sometimes your biggest rival today could be your most valuable ally tomorrow.

That's not just tech history. 
That's brilliance.

-

sample_posts.hook: This man built a $32 BILLION empire selling "worthless" junk online.
sample_posts.full_content:
This man built a $32 BILLION empire selling "worthless" junk online.
In 1995, he auctioned off a broken laser pointer as a joke for $14...
And created a website that inspired Amazon, Etsy, AND Shopify.
Here's proof that one person's trash can become anyone's treasure:

Pierre Omidyar was a 28-year-old programmer when he listed a broken laser pointer for $1 on his new website.

To his shock, someone bought it for $14.83.

The buyer wasn't collecting junk.
He saw an opportunity to repair it for way less than the $100+ retail price.

This simple insight sparked a revolution in online commerce.

And that programmer?
Pierre Omidyar

And his experiment would become eBay.

By 1996, his site hosted 250,000 auctions.

One year later? 800,000 auctions PER DAY.

Growth was so explosive, his internet bill jumped from $30 to $250 monthly.

This forced him to start charging listing fees - a decision that accidentally increased trust.

Why? People realized: If sellers paid to list items, they were probably legitimate.

But the platform faced a bigger challenge: 
Getting strangers to trust each other online.

The solution? 

A revolutionary feedback system where buyers and sellers could rate each other.

This became the blueprint for modern e-commerce trust.

In 2000, they made an even bolder move: Introducing fixed-price listings.

Critics thought it would kill the auction format.

Instead, it exploded growth - today, 90% of items sell through fixed prices.

The platform's current impact is staggering:
• 132 million active buyers
• Operations in 190 markets
• $73 billion in yearly transactions

The lesson? Innovation isn't just about technology.

It's about understanding human behavior and building systems that scale trust.

eBay didn't create this truth - they just built a platform around it.

-

Here's the key takeaways: 

In 2017, Tom G. and Herman Sahota wanted to bring Wingstop to the UK.

They had no background in restaurants and no experience in franchising

But they had conviction.

So they took the simplest, highest-leverage action possible: they sent a cold email to Wingstop Restaurants Inc.’s head of franchising.

That email landed them a conversation.

That conversation led to an opportunity.

And that opportunity turned into a UK-wide franchise of one of the fastest-growing restaurant chains in the world.

What happened next?

- They launched their first store in London.
- They scaled to 57 locations across the UK.
- They built a team of 2,500+ employees.
- They crossed £150M+ in revenue.

And at the end of 2024, they sold the business for $400 million.

All of it started with one email.

So send that email - but make it damn good.

My top 3 Clay workflows that you can set-up today 

Helping me book over 2,000+ meetings ⤴️ 

These workflows help us daily with automating our outbound sales and marketing.

Flow 1 - Enriching Web Traffic  

Flow 2 - Meta Ads Identification 

Flow 3 - Calendly Lead Qualification

Flow 1 - Enriching Web Traffic

From here, you can run any enrichments you want.

- Find phone numbers and emails with Findymail

Plus, any other enrichments you can think of.

Send the enriched leads to Slack and/or add them to an Instantly.ai outbound campaign.


Flow 2 - Meta Ads Identification

Perform a store leads company search inside of Clay.

Add those leads to a new table.

Add the Facebook page link as a new column.

Use the BuiltWith integration and search for the Facebook pixel using their domain.

From here, for any leads that have a pixel installed on their site:

Run an Apify enrichment — specifically the Facebook-ads-scraper Apify.
Use this as the input data:

Use this as the input data - 

{ "onlyTotal": true, "resultsLimit": 20, "startUrls": [{"url": Facebook Page Link}] }

From here, you can see which leads are running ads based on what it scrapes.


Flow 3 - Calendly Lead Qualification

Create an automation in Zapier that triggers when a new event is created in Calendly.

From here, send that data to a Clay table.

Once the data is in the table, run a company enrichment (search for 'Enrich Company').

- LinkedIn
- Description, etc.

Run any other enrichments that might help you qualify a lead.

sample_posts.hook: 5 Step All-Bound System for Your B2B Company
sample_posts.full_content:
5 Step All-Bound System for Your B2B Company 

This is what's working now (not mass cold outbound)...

Here’s what we’re currently setting up for companies:

Our offering last year: mainly larger-scale outbound/volume campaigns.

Our offering in January 2025: inbound/outbound demand generation and capture. Outbound based on lead intent 

Why we needed to change what we do:

- Email deliverability is extremely hard to get right.
- Lower barrier to entry.

The Process

1 - Know your ICP and own the data

Knowing exactly who and where your ICP is key. 

Start by building a hyper-targeted list of companies or people you would ideally work with. 

From here, you can proceed without needing an expensive data source. 

Just add loads of filters and use Clay AI to find your ICP.

- Apollo.io
- ListKit
- Instantly.ai
- ocean.io


2 - Create a modern outbound system

- 50-100 domains.
- 5-10 emails per domain per day.
- Only send to Google domains.
- Short email with no spam words.

Only reach out to hyper-segmented and targeted lists with a relevant offer and reason to contact. Include trigger-based systems. 

Use offsite tools like Vector 👻 to identify in-market leads, then use Clay to process, enrich, and add them to an Instantly.ai campaign.


3 - Create a company content system

Authority and trust are the key differences between someone buying from you or a competitor. 

Yes, it takes time to be effective, but once it’s there, it’s lasting. This is why big brands thrive. 

I recently created a post explaining how you can get yourself and your team to post high-quality content on LinkedIn. 

I also suggest creating content for a blog and any other channel your ICP views.


4 - Capture and identify demand from your inbound

We need to identify content viewers in your ICP so we can target them. 

To do this, use a tool like Trigify.io for LinkedIn content. 

For other platforms, use lead magnets to capture contact info, providing value to the marketplace (this only works if the lead magnet is good). 

Push these leads to Clay for enrichment.


5 - Convert outbound demand

The same goes for outbound: we need to convert positive replies into meetings or sales.

Rule #1: Reply within 15 minutes of receiving a response—this is vital to increase the meeting booking rate. 

Track all replies and send them into a CRM, which you can do with an Instantly.ai + Zapier integration.

------

This is what is working right now. Make the most of it while you can.

Message me if you’d like a more in-depth breakdown.

--- Play 1 → Website Traffic → Email ---

Vector 👻 → Clay → Findymail → Instantly.ai

This play essentially identifies account level US traffic with Vector, pushes the lead into clay where it can be enriched as much or as little as you desire. Then adding the lead into Instantly. 

1 - Set up a Vector account.
2 - Connect to Clay via a webhook.
3 - In Clay, create a table and select "Monitor Webhook."
4 - Set up and test enrichments & qualification filters.
5 - Add a column, search for "Add lead to Instantly campaign."
6 - Map fields and add extra info for Slack.


--- Play 2 → Ad Click → Slack ---

Vector 👻 → Clay → Findymail → Slack

This is very similar to the play above. Uses Vectors Ad reveal feature to tack clicks on your ads. From here it's the same process as play 1 

1 - Set up a Vector account.
2 - Connect to Clay via a webhook.
3 - In Clay, create a table and select "Monitor Webhook."
4 - Set up and test enrichments & qualification filters.
5 - Add a column, search for "Send message to Slack."
6 - Map fields and add extra info for Slack.


--- Play 3 → Content engagement → Slack ---

Trigify.io → Clay → Findymail → Slack

This play allows us to take content engagement, push it into clay and reach out 

1 - Connect LinkedIn accounts to monitor.
2 - Go to "Integrations" and connect to Clay via a webhook.
3 - In Clay, create a table and select "Monitor Webhook."
4 - Set up and test enrichments & qualification filters.
5 - Add a column, search for "Add lead to Instantly campaign."
6 - Map fields and add extra info for Instantly.
7 - Run a test to verify leads go to the correct Instantly campaign.


--- Play 4 → Positive Reply → Slack ---

Instantly.ai → Zapier → Slack

This is super useful to keep on top of quick responses to outbound emails. We take positive replies in instantly and push them as a notification in slack (Yes this one doesn't involve clay, but it's a must have)

1 - Create new zapier automation 
2 - Select Instantly as the trigger 
3 - Pick 'lead marked as interested'
4 - Choose slack as the second part of the automation 
5 - Input the desired message an variables from Instantly 

--- Play 5 → Monitor signals → Email ---

Monitor job titles changes, job changes and new hires using clay, enrich and run relevant emails 

1 - Create a new clay table
2 - Choose desired signal to monitor 
3 - Upload or scrape desired list to monitor 
4 - Enrich in clay 
5 - Add a column, search for "Add lead to Instantly campaign."
6 - Map fields and add extra info for Instantly.
7 - Run a test to verify leads go to the correct Instantly campaign.

----

That's a wrap for this one. These are just some of the flows you could use

sample_posts.hook: My intro calls were costing us $30,000+ per deal. Like, Most AEs I danced around the real questions—afraid of being too direct. But asking the right questions, at the right time, has taken our ACV from $2K to over $30K for all new opportunities.
sample_posts.full_content:
My intro calls were costing us $30,000+ per deal. Like, Most AEs I danced around the real questions—afraid of being too direct. But asking the right questions, at the right time, has taken our ACV from $2K to over $30K for all new opportunities.

Here's the Story:

We've all been on an intro call.

Talking to a new prospect. With limited information.

Trying to figure it out.

Why are they here? (Understanding pain & urgency)

If that is solved, then trying to find...

How do they actually buy? (Eliminating roadblocks)

Most reps (including myself) focus too much on the first and completely fumble the second.


1) The Discovery Phase: Ask Harder Questions

In the beginning of my selling journey, like many AEs, I was sugarcoating questions like, “Does this seem interesting?” Instead, get to the real motivation:

↳ “Why are you here?” (If inbound, don’t assume—make them say it.)
↳  "If we could achieve [X], what would that mean for the company?” Follow up: “And why is that important?”
↳ “What’s in it for you personally?” (Bonus? Promotion? Job security?)

Going one level deeper creates urgency. It shifts the conversation from “just exploring” to “I need this now.”

Doing this well gets them to a "soft yes".


2) The Next Steps Phase: Stop Chasing, Start Closing

How many prospects say “this sounds great” and then disappear? What fixed it for me was these kind of direct questions:

↳ “Do you see anyone internally opposing this?” (Identify silent deal-killers.)
↳ “Are you the sole decision-maker?” If yes, close them now. If not, ask: 
↳ “What does your boss typically care about?”
↳ “Can we get on a call with them before you pitch internally?”

Eliminate all major roadblocks. Give them the tools to sell internally.

Which is where most new deals get shot down.

Getting in front of after call objections. 

Helps both the buyer and the seller.

---

I've learned the best AEs don’t “hope” deals close. 

They make sure of it—on the call.

Any good questions I'm missing? Drop it below.

sample_posts.full_content:
I booked 10 meetings in one day last week—all through LinkedIn and 30 messages.

Tuesday started like any other.

I made my daily LinkedIn post and responded to a few messages from the night before.

Then, I came across a sales coach who said something that stuck with me:
Closed/lost leads are goldmines.

So, I put it to the test.

I opened up my Kondo account (shoutout to Mitchell Tan 📮) and dug into the archives—thousands of past conversations from the last six months. I filtered for decision-makers and sent 30 personalized messages.

Within minutes, responses started rolling in.

We talked about 
- Life
- Work
- Weekend adventures

After some conversation it turned out that 10 of them were still struggling with outbound and they actually wanted to give BirdDog a try, but had just been casually seeing my posts on Linkedin about company updates. 

They had been "meaning to try it"

So, I booked meetings to catch them up on the latest with BirdDog. This was my version of closed/lost follow-up—dead conversations from months ago turning into real opportunities.

The best leads aren’t always new. Sometimes, they’re just waiting for the right moment.

sample_posts.full_content:
"Are you really going to stop that on January 31st" - Founder of Eight Companies. 

My Answer: "Yes, of course"

A little over 4 months ago, Noah and I launched BirdDog officially to the world.

Our very first pricing model was split into three levels:

> Solo - $165/mo
> Growth - $320/mo/seat
> Team - $635/mo/seat

But there was always the caveat that solo was ending Jan 31st, 2025. 

So, I am happy and sad to say our lowest price plan will be removed. This change will allow Noah and I to focus on the multi-seat larger ticket deals that will get us to our 2025 goal.

We've had a lot of AEs, Founders, and Individuals take us up on our lowest level because it is 'cheap' enough where the time saved/extra deals closed more than make them happy to pay for the platform each month.

This means finding signals, sending alert emails, discovering decision makers, and doing all the background research to make personalized messaging that "Wow's" prospects.

All that being said....

9 days left, until Noah and I go all in on hunting some big deals. It's going to be an awesome year.

sample_posts.full_content:
Bragging isn't selfish. It’s your duty as a Founder & CEO. If you’ve built something great but stay quiet, you are making a choice. A choice not to give your business the advantage it deserves.

Most Founders hesitate to share their success because they think it’s arrogant or "salesy". But bragging isn’t about ego, it’s about proving your credibility.

If people don’t believe in your expertise, they won’t listen. And if they don’t listen, they won’t buy.

The Solution: The Credibility Statement
Use it at the beginning of every long-form video and live video.

It answers three critical questions in 10 seconds or less:
Who are you?
What have you done?
Where should I go next to learn more?

Here’s how to do it right.

1. Be Clear About What You Have Done

Weak: I am a consultant with 15 years of experience.

Strong: I train tech sales teams with 1,000+ employees. We have worked with global brands like Nike and Kroger and helped them increase close rates by 35%.

Formula: I am a [X] that does [X] for [X] type of clients. My work has resulted in [X measurable result].



2. Show How Many People You Have Helped

Weak: I am a coach who has worked with several clients.

Strong: I am a fitness coach who has helped 37 clients, and 90% of them lost 20 pounds or more in their first six weeks.

Formula: I have helped [X] clients achieve [X measurable result] in [X timeframe].



3. Tell Them Where to Go Next

Weak: I post about LinkedIn growth.

Strong: My name is Shaneee Moret, I have almost 1M followers on LinkedIn. If you're a founder who wants to learn how to grow on LinkedIn, go to yougrow.club.

Formula: My name is [X], I have [X achievement]. If you’re [X audience] who wants to [X goal], go to [X website or resource].

Own your success, or someone with half your results will. And they’ll get the opportunities you could have had.

#marketing #personalbranding #strategy

The business owners that win in 2025 will be the ones that go LIVE. It’s not about perfection—it’s about proving you care by showing up and helping people in real time.

How I saved a tech company $128,557 in 22 days 

(without hiring more staff):

$128,557. Gone.  

All because they didn’t trust their CRM to do its job.  

Here’s the story:  

- 185 employees  
- A growing tech company
- Held back by CRM inefficiencies  

Their marketing director was wasting 5.5 hours a day on low-level tasks:  

Manually entering lead data into three CRMs:
  
- HubSpot  
- Google Sheets  
- Salesforce  

The result?  

- Typos and bad data  
- Gut-feeling decisions  
- Delayed reporting  

Let’s crunch the numbers:  

110 hours a month—lost.
165 working days a year—wasted.
A staggering $128,557—down the drain.

Here’s how we fixed it:  

First, discovery. We identified every inefficiency and bottleneck.  

Then, build. We integrated HubSpot with Salesforce and eliminated Google Sheets.  

Finally, testing. Everything was run in Salesforce Sandbox, approved, and launched.  

22 days later, their system ran like clockwork.  

The result?  

110 hours saved every month  
$128,557 in yearly costs eliminated  
And their marketing director? Back to focusing on real high-level work.  

P.S. What’s one inefficiency that’s holding your business back right now?

name: michael-houck
top_hooks: Tech companies are getting scammed by engineers.
A startup starts with a problem.

sample_posts.creator: michael-houck
sample_posts.hook: Tech companies are getting scammed by engineers.
sample_posts.full_content:
Tech companies are getting scammed by engineers.

Everyone thinks this is an exaggeration, but there are so many software engineers who literally get paid $300k to work less than 5 hours per week.

They make 2 or 3 code changes per month, send some emails and show up for a few meetings while working remotely.

The worst offenders even have multiple jobs like this at the same time and brag about it on reddit.

And this isn’t because of AI. Most of them are so tuned out that they don’t even realize how good AI has gotten (and that their jobs might be at risk as a result).

This is why NO ONE in Silicon Valley was actually surprised that Elon was able to lay off 80% of Twitter with no negative impact.

The bloat is an open secret in tech. Millions of dollars are being wasted on salaries.

sample_posts.full_content:
THE BEST WAY to learn about:

1. Niche small business ideas
2. How saturated (or not) an industry is in your market

Is to post a small warehouse for rent on FB Marketplace.

Don't own one? That's fine. Post a picture of one just to learn.

I happen to own one, and it is so fascinating to learn the types of businesses people own and how well they are doing.

These are a few I've learned about:

- Classic car storage

- Hot air balloon repair (Chick Fil A is their biggest customer)

- Art studio rental (think WeWork for small art studios)

- Concession trailers

All from this little ugly warehouse. There is no shortage of demand for these things.

Someone needs to raise a couple hundred mill to build or buy a ton of them in the exurbs.

Follow me Chris Koerner if you found this interesting!

sample_posts.creator: cjkoerner
sample_posts.hook: Want to get a product sold in retail? It’s actually quite simple:
sample_posts.full_content:
Want to get a product sold in retail? It’s actually quite simple:

1. Enlist your friends and family or hire some VAs

2 Give them a list of store numbers in an area. Let’s say all Dallas Krogers

3 Have them continually call and ask if they carry your product

4 After a while your brand is top of mind

5 Reach out to the buyer with your pitch and close the deal

This is actually more common than you think. Landing stores isn’t even the hardest part. 

The hardest part is getting sell-through. AKA ensuring that walk in customers actually buy your product more than once. 

If you can do both, you’re golden. 

Follow me Chris Koerner  for more growth hacks.

sample_posts.hook: 97% of CEOs plan to integrate AI, but only 1.7% feel fully prepared.
sample_posts.full_content:
97% of CEOs plan to integrate AI, but only 1.7% feel fully prepared.

Why is there such a big gap between ambition and readiness?
A new study from Cisco, based on insights from 2,503 CEOs worldwide, reveals what’s holding leaders back—and how they plan to bridge the gap.

Key Findings from the study

Positive Trends
→ 97% of CEOs plan to integrate AI into operations.
→ 80% believe AI will bring major benefits.
→ 96% are securing partnerships to future-proof their networks.
→ 79% say their CTO/CIO plays a critical role in AI adoption.

Challenges
→ Only 1.7% of CEOs feel fully prepared for AI implementation.
→ 74% worry knowledge gaps will impact boardroom decisions.
→ 70% fear losing competitive edge due to IT and infrastructure gaps.
→ 58% worry AI adoption struggles will slow business growth.
→ 53% are already losing ground due to underinvestment in technology.


My Call to CEOs: Stop Talking, Start Executing

→ Start executing as soon as possible. Tomorrow is too late. 
AI isn’t something to plan for “someday.” It’s already transforming industries. If you don’t act now, you’ll be playing catch-up while others lead.

→ Start small. 
You don’t need a massive AI transformation to make an impact. Pick a project that can be executed quickly—something simple but valuable. Test, refine, and build momentum.

→ Focus on high-impact, low-effort wins first. 
Find the quick wins—process automation, data insights, or AI-driven customer interactions—that deliver immediate value with minimal disruption. These will prove AI’s worth and help secure buy-in for bigger moves.

→ Upskill your team.
AI adoption isn’t just about technology—it’s about people. Your team will drive this change, but only if they have the right skills. Invest in AI literacy, training, and experimentation.

→ Be open to challenges and possible failures. 
AI adoption is a process of learning. Not everything will work immediately, and that’s okay. The companies that succeed are the ones willing to iterate, adapt, and push forward.


AI isn’t the future—it’s the present. The winners will be those who do, not just discuss.

What’s stopping more CEOs from taking action? Fear? Uncertainty? Lack of leadership? Let me know what you think in the comments.

---

sample_posts.hook: Baidu’s Big AI Move: ERNIE X1 & ERNIE 4.5
sample_posts.full_content:
Baidu’s Big AI Move: ERNIE X1 & ERNIE 4.5
China’s AI race just got more intense. Baidu has launched two new AI models—ERNIE X1 and ERNIE 4.5—challenging OpenAI and DeepSeek. 

And the biggest surprise? They made them free for individual users before the official release date.What do these models bring to the table?

ERNIE X1: Baidu’s Deep-Thinking AI

→ Specialized for reasoning – Designed for complex problem-solving, logical thinking, and in-depth analysis.
 → Tool integration – Supports search, document Q&A, coding, image understanding, and even business intelligence.
 → Half the price of DeepSeek R1 – Enterprise API starts at $0.28 per million tokens, making it one of the most cost-effective AI reasoning models.

ERNIE 4.5: Multimodal Powerhouse

→ Understands text, images, audio, and video – Enhanced comprehension across multiple formats.
 → Beats GPT-4.5? – Baidu claims it outperforms OpenAI’s latest model on key benchmarks.
 → Extreme cost advantage – Priced at 1% of GPT-4.5's cost, making advanced AI dramatically cheaper.

Baidu’s Bold Strategy

→ Free access for users – Anyone can now try ERNIE models without a subscription.
 → Open-source shift – ERNIE 4.5 will become open-source by June 30, following the strategy that made DeepSeek widely adopted.
 → Targeting global AI dominance – With aggressive pricing and strong multimodal performance, Baidu is positioning itself as a major competitor against OpenAI.

The question now: Is this a significant change in the landscape, or will pricing alone not be enough to shift AI dominance?
